sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 1
sentence.feature: Dataset 1. Subject-verb-object (SVO)
sentence.text: A mama fon a pikin.
sentence.gloss: The mother beat the child.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 6
sentence.feature: Dataset 2. Possessum-possessor
sentence.text: a buba fu a tigri
sentence.gloss: the tiger’s pelt

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 3
sentence.feature: Dataset 2. Possessor-possessum
sentence.text: Charles oto
sentence.gloss: Charles' car

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 5
sentence.feature: Dataset 2. Possessor-possessum
sentence.text: mi masra famiri oso
sentence.gloss: my husband’s family’s house

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 9
sentence.feature: Dataset 3. Modifying adjective precedes noun
sentence.text: soso dungru katun krosi
sentence.gloss: only dark cotton clothes

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press.
sentence.feature: Dataset 4. Prepositions
sentence.text: Mi e go na mi mama oso.
sentence.gloss: I’m going to my mother’s house.

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press.
sentence.feature: Dataset 4. Prepositions
sentence.text: A bedi de na a karma ini.
sentence.gloss: The bed is in the room

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press. Example 11
sentence.feature: Dataset 4. Prepositions
sentence.text: ini a yari fu 1492
sentence.gloss: in the year 1492

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press. Example 13
sentence.feature: Dataset 4. Prepositions
sentence.text: Mi de na mi mama oso.
sentence.gloss: I’m at my mother’s house.

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 1996. On identifying instances of grammaticalization in creole languages. In Baker, Philip and Syea, Anand (eds.), Changing meanings, changing functions: Papers related to grammaticalization in contact languages, 29-46. London: University of Westminster Press. Example 15
sentence.feature: Dataset 4. Prepositions
sentence.text: A bedi de na ini a kamra.
sentence.gloss: The bed is in the room.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 19
sentence.feature: Dataset 5. Demonstrative word follows noun
sentence.text: den sani disi
sentence.gloss: these things

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 20
sentence.feature: Dataset 6. Numeral precedes noun
sentence.text: den seibi lowe srafu
sentence.gloss: the seven runaway slaves

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 22
sentence.feature: Dataset 7. Relative clause follows noun
sentence.text: a tori disi san mi e go taki
sentence.gloss: the story that I’m going to tell

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 26
sentence.feature: Dataset 8. Degree word follows adjective
sentence.text: A watra faya bun.
sentence.gloss: The water is very hot.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 23
sentence.feature: Dataset 8. Degree word precedes adjective
sentence.text: John moro bigi.
sentence.gloss: John's bigger.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 28
sentence.feature: Dataset 8. Degree word precedes adjective
sentence.text: A liba de tumsi bradi fu swen abra.
sentence.gloss: The river is too broad to swim across.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 30
sentence.feature: Dataset 8. Degree word precedes adjective
sentence.text: John de moro bigi leki Peter.
sentence.gloss: John’s bigger than Peter.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 32
sentence.feature: Dataset 9. Definite article is preposed
sentence.text: Den si den ingi.
sentence.gloss: They saw the Indians.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 34
sentence.feature: Dataset 10. Indefinite article is preposed
sentence.text: Dati a wan nengre leki den srefi.
sentence.gloss: That is a black man like themselves.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 38
sentence.feature: Dataset 11. Adverb – verb – object
sentence.text: Ala yuru a man disi e kon tanteri mi.
sentence.gloss: This man comes and bothers me all the time.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 37
sentence.feature: Dataset 11. Verb – object – adverb
sentence.text: Mi bari a pikin nofrotron fu no waka nanga den boi dati.
sentence.gloss: I warned the child often not to hang around with those boys.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 40
sentence.feature: Dataset 12. Interrogative phrase initial
sentence.text: Sanede yu du dati?
sentence.gloss: Why did you do that?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 42
sentence.feature: Dataset 13. No gender distinctions
sentence.text: En na mi mati.
sentence.gloss: He/She is my friend.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1984. A sketch of Sranan Tongo. In Pet, Willem (ed.), Papers on Sranan Tongo, 8-123. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. Example 44
sentence.feature: Dataset 15. Inclusive and exclusive differentiated
sentence.text: Wi e kon dalék.
sentence.gloss: We're coming right away.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1984. A sketch of Sranan Tongo. In Pet, Willem (ed.), Papers on Sranan Tongo, 8-123. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. Example 45
sentence.feature: Dataset 15. Inclusive and exclusive differentiated
sentence.text: Un prisiri sote!
sentence.gloss: We really enjoyed ourselves.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 45
sentence.feature: Dataset 16. Syncretism between 1st and 2nd person
sentence.text: Un prisiri sote!
sentence.gloss: We really enjoyed ourselves.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 48
sentence.feature: Dataset 19. Interrogative pronouns: Two compound expressions
sentence.text: Pe yu kmopo?
sentence.gloss: Where did you come from?

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 50
sentence.feature: Dataset 19. Interrogative pronouns: Two compound expressions
sentence.text: Oten wi o drai go baka?
sentence.gloss: When will we return?

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 52
sentence.feature: Dataset 20. Singular pronoun overtly conjoined with other conjunct
sentence.text: Mi nanga Arnie e tan ini a srefi birti.
sentence.gloss: Arnie and I live in the same neighborhood.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 54
sentence.feature: Dataset 21. Generic-noun-based indefinites
sentence.text: A gersi sani e dringi mi brudu.
sentence.gloss: It's like something is drinking my blood.

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 2002. The structure of the Surinamese Creoles. In Carlin, Eithne B. and Arends, Jacques (eds.), Atlas of the Languages of Suriname, 153-182. Leiden: KITLV Press. Example 56
sentence.feature: Dataset 22. Variable plural marking of human or inanimate nouns
sentence.text: den uma
sentence.gloss: the women

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn, Adrienne. 2002. The structure of the Surinamese Creoles. In Carlin, Eithne B. and Arends, Jacques (eds.), Atlas of the Languages of Suriname, 153-182. Leiden: KITLV Press. Example 55
sentence.feature: Dataset 25. Identity between nominal plural marker and third-person-plural pronoun
sentence.text: den oso
sentence.gloss: the houses

sentence.source: Apics. Smith, Norval S.H. 2003. New Evidence from the Past: To Epenthesize or Not to Epenthesize? That is the tags['question']. In Plag, Ingo (ed.), Phonology and Morphology of Creole Languages, 91-107. Tübingen: Niemeyer. Braun, Maria. 2009. Word-formation and creolisation. The Case of Early Sranan. Tübingen: Niemeyer. Example 58
sentence.feature: Dataset 26. Functions of reduplication: attenuating and word-class-changing function
sentence.text: Norfu e férfi-férfi.
sentence.gloss: Norval is painting a bit.

sentence.source: Apics. Smith, Norval S.H. 2003. New Evidence from the Past: To Epenthesize or Not to Epenthesize? That is the tags['question']. In Plag, Ingo (ed.), Phonology and Morphology of Creole Languages, 91-107. Tübingen: Niemeyer. Braun, Maria. 2009. Word-formation and creolisation. The Case of Early Sranan. Tübingen: Niemeyer. Example 60
sentence.feature: Dataset 26. Functions of reduplication: attenuating and word-class-changing function
sentence.text: a oso férfi-ferfi
sentence.gloss: The house was/has been painted several times.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 62
sentence.feature: Dataset 28. Definite article distinct from demonstratives
sentence.text: Den ten disi a son e faya.
sentence.gloss: These days the sun is hot.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 64
sentence.feature: Dataset 29. Indefinite article identical to numeral 'one'
sentence.text: Wan ben tron datra srefi.
sentence.gloss: One even became a doctor.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 66
sentence.feature: Dataset 29. Indefinite article identical to numeral 'one'
sentence.text: Dus no wan, no wan fu unu ben man bai a unusrefi.
sentence.gloss: So none of us could buy from each other.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 68
sentence.feature: Dataset 30. Bare singular noun phrase in languages with definite article
sentence.text: Fowru e singi, dagu e bari.
sentence.gloss: Birds sing, dogs bark

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 70
sentence.feature: Dataset 31. Co-occurrence of demonstrative and definite article
sentence.text: A man disi sabi a tori.
sentence.gloss: This guy knows the story.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford transcripts. Example 71
sentence.feature: Dataset 32. Pronominal and adnominal demonstratives: same forms
sentence.text: Disi a fu un bori.
sentence.gloss: This is for us to cook.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford transcripts. Example 73
sentence.feature: Dataset 32. Pronominal and adnominal demonstratives: same forms
sentence.text: Mi begi, yu no kan fergiti dati tog.
sentence.gloss: I prayed, you can’t forget that, right.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford transcripts. Example 75
sentence.feature: Dataset 33. Distance contrasts in demonstratives: two-way contrast
sentence.text: a man dati
sentence.gloss: than man

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 77
sentence.feature: Dataset 35. Ordinal numerals
sentence.text: di fu tu
sentence.gloss: second

sentence.source: Apics. Windford transcripts. Example 20
sentence.feature: Dataset 36. Sortal numeral classifiers: the language has no numeral classifiers
sentence.text: den seibi lowe srafu
sentence.gloss: the seven runaway slaves

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 80
sentence.feature: Dataset 37. Marking of pronominal possessors: preceding word
sentence.text: Mi futu no de so bigi.
sentence.gloss: My feet are not so big.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 82
sentence.feature: Dataset 37. Marking of pronominal possessors: adpositional phrase following the possessum
sentence.text: Dan a no man nanga a ouderwets sani fu en.
sentence.gloss: Then he can’t put up with her old-fashioned ways

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 84
sentence.feature: Dataset 37. Marking of pronominal possessors: adpositional phrase following the possessum
sentence.text: den srafu fu den
sentence.gloss: their slaves

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 85
sentence.feature: Dataset 38. Marking of possessor noun phrases: adpositional or case marking of possessor
sentence.text: A plan fu a Masra e go doro.
sentence.gloss: The Lord’s plan continues.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 87
sentence.feature: Dataset 38. Marking of possessor noun phrases: no marking
sentence.text: Den bigi suma taki yu kan kibri yu granmama bere.
sentence.gloss: The older folk say you can hide your grandmother’s belly.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 89
sentence.feature: Dataset 39. Identical to dependent pronominal possessor
sentence.text: A buku disi na fu mi.
sentence.gloss: This book is mine.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 24
sentence.feature: Dataset 41. Comparative adjective marking: adjective is marked
sentence.text: A oloisi disi moro diri.
sentence.gloss: This watch is more expensive.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 92
sentence.feature: Dataset 41. Comparative adjective marking: adjective is not marked
sentence.text: John bigi moro Peter.
sentence.gloss: John’s bigger than Peter.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 93
sentence.feature: Dataset 42. Comparative standard marking: secondary surpass marking
sentence.text: Amba tranga pasa Kofi.
sentence.gloss: Amba is stronger than Kofi.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 95
sentence.feature: Dataset 42. Comparative standard marking: secondary surpass marking
sentence.text: A oloisi disi moro diri moro a dati.
sentence.gloss: This watch is more expensive than that one.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 97
sentence.feature: Dataset 43. Position of tense, aspect, and mood markers in relation to the verb: immediately preceding the verb
sentence.text: Efu mi ben gudu, mi ben sa bai wan oto.
sentence.gloss: If I were rich, I would buy a car.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Creoles in the context of contact linguistics. In Gilbert, Glenn (ed.), Pidgin and creole linguistics in the 21st century, 287-354. New York: Peter Lang. Example 99
sentence.feature: Dataset 44. Internal order of tense, aspect, and mood markers: Tense-Mood-Aspect
sentence.text: Wel, dan granpa ben sa e gi den (owru tori) ma dati mi no miti.
sentence.gloss: Well, then granddad would have (habitually) told them, but I never experienced that.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Creoles in the context of contact linguistics. In Gilbert, Glenn (ed.), Pidgin and creole linguistics in the 21st century, 287-354. New York: Peter Lang. Example 101
sentence.feature: Dataset 44. Internal order of tense, aspect, and mood markers: Tense-Mood-Aspect
sentence.text: A ben musu e taki nanga en m’ma.
sentence.gloss: She must have been talking to her mother.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 104
sentence.feature: Dataset 46. Tightness of the link between the progressive marker and the verb: particle, nothing can intervene
sentence.text: Dus suma pikin e musu meki muyti.
sentence.gloss: So the children must do their best.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins.
sentence.feature: Dataset 47. Uses of the progressive marker: progressive, habitual, and current state
sentence.text: En efu a man dati wini en, a kondre e kon bun zeker.
sentence.gloss: And if that man wins it [the election], the country will surely improve.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 106
sentence.feature: Dataset 47. Uses of the progressive marker: progressive, habitual, and current state
sentence.text: Mi e sidon dya, mi e denki fu beroof wan bangi now de.
sentence.gloss: I’m sitting here thinking to rob a bank right now.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 108
sentence.feature: Dataset 47. Uses of the progressive marker: progressive, habitual, and current state
sentence.text: Yu no e sabi a wet so bun.
sentence.gloss: You don’t really know the law so well.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 110
sentence.feature: Dataset 47. Uses of the progressive marker: progressive, habitual, and current state
sentence.text: Den no e wani taki Sranan Tongo moro.
sentence.gloss: They don't want to speak Sranan Tongo anymore.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 9
sentence.feature: Dataset 48. Uses of the habitual marker: habitual, progressive, and current state
sentence.text: soso dungru katun krosi
sentence.gloss: only dark cotton clothes

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 110
sentence.feature: Dataset 48. Uses of the habitual marker: habitual, progressive, and current state
sentence.text: Den no e wani taki Sranan Tongo moro.
sentence.gloss: They don't want to speak Sranan Tongo anymore.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 116
sentence.feature: Dataset 48. Uses of the habitual marker: habitual, progressive, and current state
sentence.text: A pikin e krin en kamra.
sentence.gloss: The child is cleaning her room.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 118
sentence.feature: Dataset 48. Uses of the habitual marker: habitual, progressive, and current state
sentence.text: Efu yu no wroko, dan you no o nyan, tog.
sentence.gloss: If you don’t work, then you won’t eat, right?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 116
sentence.feature: Dataset 49. Mixed aspectual-temporal system
sentence.text: A pikin e krin en kamra.
sentence.gloss: The child is cleaning her room.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 114
sentence.feature: Dataset 49. Mixed aspectual-temporal system
sentence.text: Di mi kon na oso esde a ben skrifi tu brifi kaba.
sentence.gloss: When I came to the house yesterday, he had already written two letters.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 117
sentence.feature: Dataset 50. Same TAM marking in negated clauses
sentence.text: A man wani taki den kaw musu go pupe.
sentence.gloss: The man wanted the cows to relieve themselves.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 119
sentence.feature: Dataset 50. Same TAM marking in negated clauses
sentence.text: Ma yu no musu du den sani dati.
sentence.gloss: But you mustn’t do those things.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 121
sentence.feature: Dataset 51. Stative verbs with present reference and dynamic verbs with past perfective reference are both unmarked
sentence.text: A pikin wani go sribi.
sentence.gloss: The child wants to go and sleep.

sentence.source: Apics. Seuren, Pieter. 1981. Tense and aspect in Sranan. Linguistics 19. 1043-1076. Example 123
sentence.feature: Dataset 52. Inchoative expressed by progressive marker
sentence.text: Safrisafri mi e sabi den pasi kba.
sentence.gloss: I’m slowly getting to know the roads.

sentence.source: Apics. Seuren, Pieter. 1981. Tense and aspect in Sranan. Linguistics 19. 1043-1076. Example 125
sentence.feature: Dataset 52. Inchoative expressed by progressive marker
sentence.text: A pikin e kon breiti.
sentence.gloss: The child is becoming happy.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302.
sentence.feature: Dataset 55. Ability verb also expresses epistemic possibility
sentence.text: Kande Jan ben sribi kaba.
sentence.gloss: Perhaps John was already asleep.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 128
sentence.feature: Dataset 55. Ability verb also expresses epistemic possibility
sentence.text: A kan de taki Jan ben sribi kaba.
sentence.gloss: It’s possible that John was already asleep.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 130
sentence.feature: Dataset 56. The prohibitive: normal imperative construction and normal negator
sentence.text: No naki en!
sentence.gloss: Don’t hit it!

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 132
sentence.feature: Dataset 56. The prohibitive: normal imperative construction and normal negator
sentence.text: A no e naki en.
sentence.gloss: He doesn’t hit it.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 134
sentence.feature: Dataset 57. No marking of patient NPs
sentence.text: So den losi pom nanga kuku nanga ala den sortu sani.
sentence.gloss: That’s how they baked pom and cake and all that stuff.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 135
sentence.feature: Dataset 57. No marking of patient NPs
sentence.text: Den nyan unu sturu bij.
sentence.gloss: They even ate our chairs.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 137
sentence.feature: Dataset 58. Alignment of case marking of full noun phrases: neutral alignment
sentence.text: Ma dan den meti no lon gwe?
sentence.gloss: But didn’t the geese run away?

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 139
sentence.feature: Dataset 59. Alignment of case marking of personal pronouns: accusative alignment
sentence.text: Mi e teki en poti ini a pan.
sentence.gloss: I take it and put it in the pan.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 141
sentence.feature: Dataset 59. Alignment of case marking of personal pronouns: accusative alignment
sentence.text: En nanga trawan kon dya nanga wan bigi sipi.
sentence.gloss: He and others came here on a big ship.

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn and Adrienne and Muysken, Pieter and Verrips, Maaike. 1999. Double-object constructions in the creole languages: development and acquisition. In DeGraff, Michel (ed.), Language creation and language change: Creolization, diachrony and development, 329-373. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press. Example 143
sentence.feature: Dataset 60. Ditransitive constructions with 'give': double-object construction
sentence.text: Mi gi a san disi wan nen.
sentence.gloss: I gave this thing a name.

sentence.source: Apics. Bruyn and Adrienne and Muysken, Pieter and Verrips, Maaike. 1999. Double-object constructions in the creole languages: development and acquisition. In DeGraff, Michel (ed.), Language creation and language change: Creolization, diachrony and development, 329-373. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press. Example 145
sentence.feature: Dataset 60. Ditransitive constructions with 'give': double-object construction
sentence.text: Dus dan a mati o gi den suma fu en a tori.
sentence.gloss: So then the friend will tell his relatives the story.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 147
sentence.feature: Dataset 61. Order of recipient and theme in ditransitive constructions: Subject – verb – recipient – theme
sentence.text: Unu no kan gi den man a disi.
sentence.gloss: You can’t give them these.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 41
sentence.feature: Dataset 62. Expression of pronominal subjects: Obligatory pronoun words
sentence.text: A de bun.
sentence.gloss: He/She/It is good/well.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 150
sentence.feature: Dataset 62. Expression of pronominal subjects: Obligatory pronoun words
sentence.text: Yu sii, unu de bezig bouw a stal drape moro bun.
sentence.gloss: You see, we’re busy making the stall there better.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 152
sentence.feature: Dataset 63. Expletive subject in ‘seem’ constructions: an expletive subject is used
sentence.text: Mi taki dan a gersi leki mi dede kba.
sentence.gloss: I said, “Then it looks like I’m already dead.”

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 155
sentence.feature: Dataset 65. Raining constructions: rain falls
sentence.text: En sontron te unu kmopo a skoro alen e kon.
sentence.gloss: And sometimes when we came from school it rained.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 157
sentence.feature: Dataset 65. Raining constructions: rain falls
sentence.text: A alen wai pikinso.
sentence.gloss: The rain has blown away a little (i.e.: It’s not raining so hard anymore.)

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 159
sentence.feature: Dataset 66. Experiencer constructions with 'headache': body-part is subject
sentence.text: Mi weri.
sentence.gloss: I’m tired.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 160
sentence.feature: Dataset 67. Experiencer constructions with 'like': experiencer is subject
sentence.text: So ma dan mi bigin lobi a sani kba.
sentence.gloss: So, but then I began to like the thing.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 162
sentence.feature: Dataset 67. Experiencer constructions with 'like': experiencer is subject
sentence.text: A frow lobi go a Holland.
sentence.gloss: His wife likes to go to the Netherlands.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 164
sentence.feature: Dataset 68. Experiencer is subject, 'fear' is verbal
sentence.text: Wan leysi mi si wan weri ede sani ma mi no e frede, yere.
sentence.gloss: Once I saw something horrible, but I was not scared.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 169
sentence.feature: Dataset 69. Instrumental expressions: serial verb
sentence.text: Kofi teki a nefi koti a brede.
sentence.gloss: Kofi cut the bread with a knife.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 171
sentence.feature: Dataset 69. Instrumental expressions: serial verb
sentence.text: Kande a taigi yu meki yu furu a heri bari nanga watra, dan yu abi fu go teki watra drape a mofo gotro, lai a bari.
sentence.gloss: Maybe she will tell you to fill the whole barrel with water, then you have to go take water from in front of the ditch and fill the barrel.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 167
sentence.feature: Dataset 69. Instrumental expressions: adposition
sentence.text: Yu kan tapu en nanga wan planga.
sentence.gloss: You can close it with a plank.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 172
sentence.feature: Dataset 70. Comitatives and instrumentals: identity
sentence.text: Dan fakansi ten dan wi e go nanga wan heri groep.
sentence.gloss: During the vacation we went with the entire group.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 174
sentence.feature: Dataset 70. Comitatives and instrumentals: identity
sentence.text: Te mi ppa e wroko dan, den e gwe nanga en.
sentence.gloss: When my father went to work then they would go with him.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 176
sentence.feature: Dataset 70. Comitatives and instrumentals: identity
sentence.text: Yu kan tapu en nanga wan planga.
sentence.gloss: You can close it with a plank.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 177
sentence.feature: Dataset 71. Noun phrase conjunction and comitative: identity
sentence.text: So den losi pom nanga kuku nanga ala den sortu sani.
sentence.gloss: That’s how they baked pom and cake and all that stuff.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 179
sentence.feature: Dataset 71. Noun phrase conjunction and comitative: identity
sentence.text: Tyari a karaaf nanga wan kan gi mi.
sentence.gloss: Fetch the pitcher and a can for me.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 181
sentence.feature: Dataset 72. Nominal and verbal conjunction: differentiation
sentence.text: Boiki papa ben prani gruntu èn a ben kewki fowru nanga wan kaw.
sentence.gloss: Boiki’s father grew vegetables, and he raised chickens and a cow.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 183
sentence.feature: Dataset 73. Predicative noun phrases: invariant copula
sentence.text: Den tu man na skowtu.
sentence.gloss: The two men are policemen.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 184
sentence.feature: Dataset 74. Predicative adjectives: variable copula
sentence.text: A liba bradi.
sentence.gloss: The river is wide.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 186
sentence.feature: Dataset 74. Predicative adjectives: variable copula
sentence.text: A bun
sentence.gloss: It's good/okay.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 188
sentence.feature: Dataset 74. Predicative adjectives: variable copula
sentence.text: A agu dati de moi kaba.
sentence.gloss: That pig is already nice and fat.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 190
sentence.feature: Dataset 75. Predicative locative phrases: invariant copula
sentence.text: A owru de baka a doro.
sentence.gloss: The machete is behind the door.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 182
sentence.feature: Dataset 76. Predicative noun phrases and predicative locative phrases: differentiation
sentence.text: Den tu sma disi na Sranansma.
sentence.gloss: These two people are Surinamese.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 189
sentence.feature: Dataset 76. Predicative noun phrases and predicative locative phrases: differentiation
sentence.text: Den pikin ben de na skoro.
sentence.gloss: The children were at school.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 192
sentence.feature: Dataset 76. Predicative noun phrases and predicative locative phrases: differentiation
sentence.text: Mi prakseri a bai disi nanga a man dati musu de brada.
sentence.gloss: I think this boy and that man must be brothers.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald and Migge, Bettina. 2008. Surinamese Creole: Morphology and syntax. In Schneider, Edgar W. (ed.), Varieties of English, Vol. 2: The Americas and the Caribbean, 693-731. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter. Example 194
sentence.feature: Dataset 76. Predicative noun phrases and predicative locative phrases: differentiation
sentence.text: Ma Sjo srefi ben de datisey.
sentence.gloss: But Sjo himself was from that area.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 196
sentence.feature: Dataset 77. Predicative possession: transitive
sentence.text: Efu yu no abi flashlait efu munkendi, yu no e sii.
sentence.gloss: If you didn’t have a flashlight or moonlight, you couldn’t see.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 198
sentence.feature: Dataset 78. Existential verb and transitive possession verb: overlap
sentence.text: Mi no abi a bribi dati.
sentence.gloss: I don’t believe so.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 200
sentence.feature: Dataset 78. Existential verb and transitive possession verb: overlap
sentence.text: Mi no abi televisi na oso.
sentence.gloss: I don’t have TV at home.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 202
sentence.feature: Dataset 78. Existential verb and transitive possession verb: overlap
sentence.text: Den abi wan singi e singi taki lespeki no de moro.
sentence.gloss: There’s a song that says that there’s no respect anymore.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 206
sentence.feature: Dataset 79. Going to named places: preposition
sentence.text: Yu ben go nanga trein na Republiek.
sentence.gloss: You went by train to Republiek.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 208
sentence.feature: Dataset 79. Going to named places: preposition
sentence.text: En a man taki te a man go a Holland dan a man o seni wan sani gi mi.
sentence.gloss: And the man said that when he went to Holland he would send something for me.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 210
sentence.feature: Dataset 80. Coming from named places: preposition
sentence.text: A granman fu den Dyuka kmopo fu Dritabiki.
sentence.gloss: The chief of the Aukeners comes from Drietabbetje.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 204
sentence.feature: Dataset 81. Motion-to and motion-from: overlap
sentence.text: A no e denki fu kon baka na oso.
sentence.gloss: It hasn’t crossed her mind to come back home.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 212
sentence.feature: Dataset 82. Transitive motion verbs 'push': serial verb construction plus preposition
sentence.text: Di a bromfiets lon drei, mi ben abi fu pusu en go na oso.
sentence.gloss: When the motorbike ran out of gas, I had to push it home.

sentence.source: Apics. Sebba, Mark. 1987. The syntax of serial verbs. An investigation into serialisation in Sranan and other languages. Amsterdam: John Benjamins. Example 214
sentence.feature: Dataset 83. Transitive motion verbs 'pull': serial verb construction plus preposition
sentence.text: Kofi hari a ston puru na ini a olo.
sentence.gloss: Kofi pulled the stone out of the hole.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 216
sentence.feature: Dataset 84. Directional serial verb constructions with 'come' and 'go': directionals exist
sentence.text: Yu kan tyari wan suma go a wan tehuis.
sentence.gloss: You can take someone to a nursing home.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 218
sentence.feature: Dataset 85. 'Take' serial verb constructions: theme of the second verb, literal interpretation possible
sentence.text: A man teki swarfu dosu fringi naki.
sentence.gloss: The man takes the matchbox and throws it and hits.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 220
sentence.feature: Dataset 85. 'Take' serial verb constructions: theme of the second verb, literal interpretation impossible
sentence.text: Mi papa e teki moro furu aandacht gi a man.
sentence.gloss: My father pays more attention to the man.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 169
sentence.feature: Dataset 85. 'Take' serial verb constructions: instrument of the second verb, no resumptive pronoun
sentence.text: Kofi teki a nefi koti a brede.
sentence.gloss: Kofi cut the bread with a knife.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 223
sentence.feature: Dataset 86. 'Give' serial verb constructions: 'give' in second position, recipient or beneficiary
sentence.text: Mi seri a oso gi en.
sentence.gloss: I sold the house to him/her.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 225
sentence.feature: Dataset 87. Reflexive constructions: compound reflexive pronoun with emphasizer
sentence.text: A koti ensrefi nanga wan nefi.
sentence.gloss: He cut himself with a knife.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 225
sentence.feature: Dataset 88. Intensifiers and reflexive pronouns are identical
sentence.text: A koti ensrefi nanga wan nefi.
sentence.gloss: He cut himself with a knife.

sentence.source: Apics. Nickel, Marilyn and Wilner, John. 1984. Papers on Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: Instituut voor Taalwetenschap. ((Summer Institute of Linguistics)). Example 228
sentence.feature: Dataset 88. Intensifiers and reflexive pronouns are identical
sentence.text: Kande en srefi e kon na foto bori na agu gi mi.
sentence.gloss: Maybe he himself comes to the city to cook the pig for me.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 230
sentence.feature: Dataset 89. Reciprocal constructions: identical and special reciprocal construction
sentence.text: Den srudati feti nanga densrefi.
sentence.gloss: The soldiers fought with each other.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 232
sentence.feature: Dataset 89. Reciprocal constructions: identical and special reciprocal construction
sentence.text: Den brasa makandra.
sentence.gloss: They hugged each other.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 234
sentence.feature: Dataset 90. Passive constructions: passive without verbal coding
sentence.text: A liba bradi kba.
sentence.gloss: The river has already been widened.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 21
sentence.feature: Dataset 92. Subject relative clauses: relative particle and gap
sentence.text: a man di gi mi a papira
sentence.gloss: the man who gave me the paper

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 239
sentence.feature: Dataset 92. Subject relative clauses: relative particle and gap
sentence.text: A sani di de nownow unu no man tyari.
sentence.gloss: What we now have is tough to bear.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 237
sentence.feature: Dataset 92. Subject relative clauses: relative pronoun
sentence.text: Den man san e meki na kondre kon sani.
sentence.gloss: The men that are causing the country to become the way it is.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 245
sentence.feature: Dataset 93. Object relative clauses: zero and gap
sentence.text: Mi srefi dya abi famiri mi no sabi.
sentence.gloss: I myself have relatives that I don’t know.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 22
sentence.feature: Dataset 93. Object relative clauses: relative pronoun
sentence.text: a tori disi san mi e go taki
sentence.gloss: the story that I’m going to tell

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 242
sentence.feature: Dataset 93. Object relative clauses: relative particle and gap
sentence.text: Mi e wani go libi nanga a man di mi o sori yu.
sentence.gloss: I want to go and live with the person that I’ll show you.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 244
sentence.feature: Dataset 93. Object relative clauses: relative particle and gap
sentence.text: Yu abi furu Sumter di mi no sabi.
sentence.gloss: There are many people by the name of Sumter that I don’t know.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2008. Atlantic creole syntax. In Kouwenberg, Silvia and Singler, John (eds.), The handbook of pidgin and creole studies, 19-47. Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell. Example 247
sentence.feature: Dataset 94. Instrument relative clauses: Relative pronoun with pied-piping
sentence.text: a nefi nanga san a koti a bred
sentence.gloss: the knife with which he cut the bread

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 251
sentence.feature: Dataset 95. Complementizer with verbs of speaking: complementizer not synchronically related to 'say'
sentence.text: Den boi taki dati den o kon tamara baka.
sentence.gloss: The boys said that they would come back tomorrow.

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 249
sentence.feature: Dataset 95. Complementizer with verbs of speaking: no complementizer
sentence.text: Da' Anansi taki, eng go proberi efi eng kan sabi fa a nemn.
sentence.gloss: Then Anansi said he would try if he could learn his name.

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 252
sentence.feature: Dataset 96. Complementizer with verbs of knowing: complementizer identical to bare 'say'
sentence.text: A no ben sab' taki na wan bigi Anansi.
sentence.gloss: He did not know that this was a grown-up Anansi.

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Example 255
sentence.feature: Dataset 97. 'Want' complement subjects: the complement subject is left implicit
sentence.text: Jan wani fu kisi moni.
sentence.gloss: Jan wants to make money.

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Example 256
sentence.feature: Dataset 256. Complements of 'think' and 'want': identical complementizer
sentence.text: Yu denki taki na ala sma o gi bun sani.
sentence.gloss: You think that everyone will give good (spirits).

sentence.source: Apics. Plag, Ingo. 1993. Sentential complementation in Sranan: On the formation of an English-based creole language. (Linguistische Arbeiten 300.) Tübingen: Max Niemeyer Verlag. Example 258
sentence.feature: Dataset 98. Complements of 'think' and 'want': identical complementizer
sentence.text: Mi denki yu kaba nanga en.
sentence.gloss: I thought you were done with it.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 260
sentence.feature: Dataset 99. Verb doubling in temporal clauses: verb doubling is not possible in temporal clauses
sentence.text: Di mi doro na oso esde, mi brada gi mi moni.
sentence.gloss: When I got home yesterday, my brother gave me money.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 262
sentence.feature: Dataset 100. Negative morpheme types: negative particle
sentence.text: Mi no si en esde.
sentence.gloss: I didn’t see him yesterday.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 118
sentence.feature: Dataset 101. Position of standard negation: before the verb
sentence.text: Efu yu no wroko, dan you no o nyan, tog.
sentence.gloss: If you don’t work, then you won’t eat, right?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 265
sentence.feature: Dataset 102. Negation and indefinite pronouns: co-occurrence with predicate negation
sentence.text: No wan suma no man verklaar yu wan oorlog tori.
sentence.gloss: No one can tell you war stories.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 267
sentence.feature: Dataset 102. Negation and indefinite pronouns: co-occurrence with predicate negation
sentence.text: Noti no pasa nanga mi.
sentence.gloss: Nothing happened to me.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 269
sentence.feature: Dataset 103. Polar tags['question']s: final tags['question'] particle
sentence.text: A film ben span, no?
sentence.gloss: The movie was exciting, wasn’t it?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2002. Tense and aspect in Sranan and the creole prototype. In McWhorter, John (ed.), Language change and language contact in pidgins and creoles, 383-442. Amsterdam/Philadelphia: John Benjamins. Example 271
sentence.feature: Dataset 103. Polar tags['question']s: only interrogative intonation
sentence.text: Nownow yu e teki en kba nownow?
sentence.gloss: Are you already recording it right now?

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 272
sentence.feature: Dataset 104. Focusing of the noun phrase: cleft with copula before focus
sentence.text: Na yu fufuru mi moni!
sentence.gloss: It’s you that stole my money.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 1997. Property items and predication in Sranan. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 12. 237-302. Example 274
sentence.feature: Dataset 105. Focusing of the noun phrase: cleft with copula before focus
sentence.text: Want na tu leisi mi nanga a man meki afsprak kaba.
sentence.gloss: Because it’s twice that the guy and I made an appointment already.

sentence.source: Apics. Winford, Donald. 2000. Irrealis in Sranan: Mood and modality in a radical creole. Journal of Pidgin and Creole Languages 15. 63-125. Example 276
sentence.feature: Dataset 105. Verb doubling and focus: verb fronted with a copy in the background clause
sentence.text: A stik yu o stik a pikin.
sentence.gloss: You’ll suffocate the child this way.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 279
sentence.feature: Dataset 106. Focus particle 'also': after the focused element
sentence.text: Yu srefi tu musu dyompu nanga wan, yu begrijp.
sentence.gloss: You too must jump with one [foot], you understand.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 278
sentence.feature: Dataset 106. Focus particle 'also': non-adjacent following
sentence.text: I mu yepi wroko tu.
sentence.gloss: You, too, must help with the work.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 1992. Wortubuku ini Sranan Tongo (Sranan Tongo – English Dictionary). Paramaribo: Summer Institute of Linguistics. Example 282
sentence.feature: Dataset 107. Vocative markers: optional vocative marker preceding noun
sentence.text: We, yere dya.
sentence.gloss: Hey, listen here.

sentence.source: Apics. Donald Winford, Ingo Plag. 2013. Sranan structure dataset. Example 284
sentence.feature: Dataset 108. Para-linguistic usages of clicks: clicks can express only affective meanings
sentence.text: A kon, a langa en mofo, a man meki wan tyuri, dan a gwe.
sentence.gloss: He came, he pouted?, the guy made a ‘suck teeth’ and went away.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 290
sentence.feature: Dataset 112. 'Hand' and 'arm': identity
sentence.text: Mi broko mi anu di mi dyompo kmopo fu a bon.
sentence.gloss: I broke my arm when I jumped out of the tree.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 293
sentence.feature: Dataset 114. 'Body hair' and 'feather': overlap
sentence.text: Mi e kan mi wiwiri mamanten yuru fosi mi e go na doro.
sentence.gloss: I comb my hair in the morning before going out.

sentence.source: Apics. Wilner, John. 2007. Wortubuku fu Sranan Tongo. Paramaribo: SIL International. Example 296
sentence.feature: Dataset 115. 'Hear' and 'smell': differentiation
sentence.text: I n'e yere?
sentence.gloss: Can't you hear?
